newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Chapter 2 talks high on Schiphol's '97 agenda.
newsitem.headline: Chapter 2 talks high on Schiphol's '97 agenda.

text.p: Amsterdam's Schiphol airport will initiate talks this year with the three remaining airlines still operating noisy Chapter 2 aircraft in and out of the Netherlands.
In an interview with Reuters, Frits Bisschop, cargo director at Schiphol said the airlines are Trans Mediterranean Airways, Affretair and Kuwait Airways.
"We would like to sit down to see how best we can maintain their business levels whilst they upgrade their aircraft fleets to newer aircraft," he said.
"They're all airlines operating scheduled services, they're lasting customers of the airport, and their countries of origin all have good long term bilateral relationships with the Netherlands."
The move was related to a continuing drive on the part of the airport operating company to restrict noisy flights in and out of Schiphol.

"We have asked the Dutch civil aviation authority Rijks Luchtvaart Diesnt not to give permits to charter operations with Chapter 2 aircraft and that means that the few hundred Chapter 2 aircraft movements we envisage in 1997 will be related to these three airlines.
All three airlines are preparing to discuss the substitution of their older aircraft with either DC 10 or Airbus aircraft.

"With this in mind we can conclude that there's definitely an end to the image that cargo operations are related to noisy older aircraft," Bisschop said. - Air Cargo Newsroom Tel+44 171 542 7706 Fax+44 171 542 5017
